if it makes you feal better to see how they are making your food then choose the bar on open kitchen. Great and cozy place for staring your Friday or weekend mornings specially I recommend their Eggs Benedict as well as all the rest of menu. They have really nice and polite staff.
Every other weekend I am here.
author: Paayaa M.

description:
I've been a fan of Hamburger Haven since I was a wee lil kid. My family, like many other church goers, would go after 9:30 mass. The owners and other waitresses are always so welcoming and very attentive throughout the meal. 

I love everything on the breakfast menu, but especially enjoy the Denver omelet, Joe's Special, smothered biscuits. Their coffee is consistently good, and the waitresses are always quick to replenish your cup. I always opp for fries with my breakfast, though their hash browns are crispy and tasty. Other faves include the cheese or mushroom burger and the patty melt. All the food is a bit on the greasy side, but hits the spot every time. 

Go to Hamburger Haven as it's a greasy spoon locale with great, quick service and tasty food.
author: Marie B.

description:
I used to come here often as a kid before they changed their signage and all.  It was a perfect spot for an early breakfast for cheap along the Clement.  

Similarly enough, those days aren't so far out there since they still have a relatively cheap breakfast special of only $5 for 2 eggs/2 sausages/and 2 hotcakes.  You can toss in a hashbrown for around $2.  But I'd strongly advise against the coffee, as it's just the typical add water kind that isn't very flavorful or strong.  

But definitely gotta love this place as its an old neighborhood favorite with the same freindly smiles saying good morning each time you come in.
author: Vincent K.

description:
Robin Williams probably ate here after a 3 day coke bender with his 20 something year old live-in nanny and I bet his eggs were really good.  He certainly looks happy in the picture.   I had the chicken sandwich with avocado and it was very tasty.  The chicken to bread ratio was good, the bun was slightly toasted, and the grill marks on the meat were exactly 1 and 3/4 inches apart which is important for displacing heat evenly through the meat to avoid salmonella poisoning.  I have no idea what I'm talking about.   
Do you remember eating a sandwich in your Grandma's kitchen?  Eating here feels sort of like that.  It's nice.
author: Starla D.

description:
What the Jesus fuck is wrong with you goddamn people? The Haven has BY FAR the best breakfast in the Inner Richmond, and the burgers are classic old-school diner goodness. I cannot believe this place doesn't get more love. 

"A filthy grease-pit in an undeserved prime corner location on Clement St"?! That is the furthest thing from the truth. It's a pleasantly low-key greasy spoon that has that perfect crowd -- a smattering of Russians, an ancient Chinese guy reading a paper at the counter, a young couple in the two-man booths, and a crazy guy talking to himself all create the perfect mise en scene. 

The breakfast is cheap and filling (seriously, get there before eleven for the breakfast special and you can get crazy full for under five dollars). The sausage links are juicy, they get my eggs perfect over medium every time, and the hashbrowns are crispy as hell.

The burgers are, admittedly not those huge hulking Niman Ranch things so popular right now, but these are honest and v. v. tasty burgers that remind me of roadside burger joints in the Midwest and South.

"Service was ok I guess; nothing too bad or too good. The restaurant wasn't very clean, and the atmosphere was quite depressing." Wrong again, dipshit. The restaurant has this great, very authentic vibe to it. Getting breakfast at one of the booths for two is one of my favorite parts of the weekend. The service is great -- Majid in particular has this very wry and dry sense of humor and keeps the coffee coming.

"If you see this place and think it's some high-end gourmet burger joint, think again!!" How fucking dumb would you to have to be to see the exterior of the Haven and think "high-end gourmet burger joint?" I'm going to say dumb enough to do these things:

1. Pee in a beer can, forget you peed in the beer can, drink your own pee, not notice.

2. Think all dogs are boys and all cats are girls.

3. Think Carlos Mencia is really "edgy."

I know I'm focusing my rage on Jerry J.'s review, but I want to be clear that I hate everyone who gave this place one star equally. I want to punch you all in your stupid eyes until you see the truth. Jesus! 
 
And yes, I'll be the first to admit the Haven is not the perfect restaurant. Do not order anything with a side of vegatables -- they're frozen veggies from a bag given a few minutes on the grill. But the pure amount of vitriol for the place here, I'm amazed. Be honest: is Q paying you guys off?

The place is a solid 4 stars, and I'm giving them an extra star to even out all the one-star reviews from you mouth-breathing cocksmears.
author: Jake S.

description:
This little diner is seemingly misplaced, considering the fact that it's surrounded by Chinese restaurants and businesses. I figured the fact that this diner still in business in this area means it must be good, so I stopped by with my dad. 

Despite the fact that this place is called Hamburger Haven, I opted to go for the Irish Breakfast in honor of St. Patrick's Day. I got 2 eggs, bacon, sausage, hash browns, and toast. 

Typical diner experience. Outdated decor, decent and cheap food (albeit greasy and salty), and service that would be slightly subpar at any real restaurant, but acceptable for a diner.  It does have cheap beer and mimosas if you want alcohol to wash down your food. 

Nothing horrible about this place, but nothing really stands out either. If you find yourself in the area and you're hankering for a diner, this is the place to go. I don't see myself making any special trips here though...and if I'm back in the area, I'll probably opt for Chinese (like I usually do) over this place unless I'm really in the mood for a diner.
author: A W.

description:
"Five Stars! Top of its class!" - if we were looking for SF's Filthiest Restaurants.

Make sure to order the salad bar -- all you can eat flies.
author: Perci N.

description:
We ordered take outs. I ordered a mushroom hamburger with potato salad and my friend wanted a cheeseburger with fries. It was quite nice since I wanted it well done; the mushrooms compliment the meat and were both very juicy and tasty. They gave us more than enough for salt, pepper, ketchup, mustard and napkins. The potato salad comes in a big cup, bit bland but I guess they are not heavy in the salt which is actually quite nice. I didn't feel thirsty after the meal so perhaps they didn't even use MSG in the food. 

I would like to try their breakfast here someday, I looked at the menu and noticed there are variety of omelette which my friend told me is very good!
author: Bella A.

description:
So what's a vegetarian like me doing eating here? Enjoying every bite!!

This place is your classic American style diner (read: VERY cozy) located right at the end of my block, making it literally the closet restaurant to my house! And what a wonderful restaurant it is, too! I'm not just biased based on its location, I really dig this place!

So their Garden Burger with fries or potato salad is what I'll usually get here, or sometimes I'll do the breakfast foods like pancakes, eggs, etc... It's all very good and the service is very friendly! I hit up this spot like 3 times in the first week I moved here, before I gathered the courage to explore further ;)

I. Love. My. New. Neighborhood!
author: P A U L.

description:
They need to close this place down.  Truly dirty.  I got eggs benedict, and it was one of the worst I ever had.  Totally overpriced for what it is.  There are far better burgers and diner fare elsewhere for the same or lesser price.

Health Inspector's report:
Score: 88 

Violation Description: 
Date Given
Date Abated
 
032 Sanitizing - Kitchen Utensils/Food-Contact Surfaces
Moderate Risk
3/30/2005
6/28/2005
 
031 Improperly Cleaned/Not Maintained Clean
Moderate Risk
3/30/2005
6/28/2005
 
028 Soap/Drying Device - Dispensers Empty
Moderate Risk
3/30/2005
6/28/2005
 
The last routine inspection for this location was on: 3/30/2005
author: Eric X.

description:
I should preface this by pointing out that I am in a good mood. With that, I will be generous and assign Hamburger Haven a 1-star.

This eatery is the polar opposite of a classy brunch place. The spectacularly poor service rendered by the overweight and overly grumpy waitress was evident from the moment I set foot indoors. I thought for a minute I had stepped into a morgue and was being greeted by Mrs. Filch. I won't even bother digging into the detail - it's not worth my time.

Re: the food, I'm almost certain that they're serving prison-grade meat and sourcing potatoes from a famine-stricken wasteland off the northern coast of Siberia. Excessively greasy and strictly mediocre at best... certainly overpriced for the quality.

This is a typical case of Yelp over-promising, the restaurant under-delivering. I'd rather spend a long day touring hell before returning to this ransacked hole in the wall again. Ciao!

P.S. I ordered a classic plate: two eggs, four sausages, toasts, and potatoes. The other person in my party ordered egg benedict. Paid ~$25 total.
author: Jack W.

description:
As I entered Hamburger Haven with my roommate, she says "Burgers feel really comfortable here!". It is a haven, after all. 10 or more different burgers, each with a quirky description. And if you're Robin Williams, you order the Patty Melt every time. Through our lunch, my roomie continued to enlighten me with her crazy Hamburger Haven obsession. 

She considers Tony the short order cook to be a culinary master, and mentioned that everyone who works at the Haven is over 40. She says it has been around for nearly 40 years--long before the likes of most other restaurants on Clement. The walls are adorned with old photographs of Clement St & San Francisco, as well as a painting of Elvis. Why? I have no clue.

The burger and fries were mediocre, it took too long & my tum tum now has the harshies. My roommate's response to this, "If it hurts, you know you're healing."

Ummm....Yeah.

Oddly enough, the haven has a Myspace:
http://www.myspace.com/hamburgerhaven

(she won't admit to creating it, though)
author: matt m.

description:
Great for breakfast!  Straight-up, griddle cooked, toast-with-butter-and-jelly breakfast.

Old diner atmosphere, plenty of counter seats, booths for 2 (I love booths for 2), another room in back for larger parties.
 
Coffee is decent and service is quick and personable, and not overly friendly which I like.  This is a great place if you want to eat, read, and be left alone, like the hero in a Dashiell Hammett story.

I had a Spanish omlette with rye toast (perfectly toasted & buttered - this is a deal-breaker for me if it is not done right).   The omlette was fluffy and buttery and full of a rich tomato-based filling.  Yum.  Hashed browns were good.

Finding a good breakfast place in this city is not that easy.  The East Coast and Midwest are full of them - out here, they are a rarity and I don't know why.  They are either overpriced or crowded or both, or too chi-chi or greasy for my tastes.  Good, simple, inexpensive food without excessive chatter - where are you?

Hamburger Haven is a breakfast find in an unlikely part of town - and I like it.  A lot.
author: Liz S.

description:
This is my FAVORITE diner in all of San Francisco. For these reasons:

1. The staff is FRIENDLY! - The husband and wife team remember me even if I've not been back for months and months. They always make me feel like a member of the family and I LOVE these people! Even the busboys give you a big smile and make you feel welcome : )

2. They have a counter! I got thrills sitting at counters when I was six and I still do now at, well, that's none of your business.

3. Great value - two eggs, wheat toast, coffee, hashbrowns and bacon for $5? Are you kidding me??? I LOVE this place!

4. Service - your coffee cup will never drop below half full - it's topped off before you even realize it's g etting low. And you pay for ONE cup of coffee.

5. hashbrowns - these are cooked to perfection! You'll notice the line cook has orderly stacks of hashbrowns neatly lined up on the grill, cooking them slowly and over the perfect heat until they're golden brown, crispy and excruciatingly delicious! Perfection.

highly recommended by me : )
author: Alison P.

description: A humble little restaurant, in a humble little town, by a humble little corner. This place has been here for as long as I can remember. I've visited this enchanted old tyme feelin' nook in a wall a couple of times with my family. Each time, I got their signature burger. As flavorfully described in my other posts, I have a love for good burgers, and I also have a love for eating each restaurants most well-known burger. To my delight hamburger haven comes up to par with its name. Indeed I was in a haven.. of hamburgers when i tore into the simple cheeseburger made medium rare. the meat was juicy, and grilled to perfection. the lettuce was crispy and fresh. The fries were soft and potatoey ;) it was a great meal. I had a great time, drinkin coca cola on the side. I highly recommend hamburger haven for all your hamburger (or cheezburger) needs.
author: simon k.

description:
This review is long over due...
I year ago, I was at this place three nights a week.  I got good food and great service, but the new staff is cold and impersonal, so I stopped going...
author: C J.

description:
There's isn't anything not to like about this place. It's been here forever, and nowadays, boasting a clean new awning. There also isn't anything about the place that sets it apart from ordinary diners either, except for its location of being the only breakfst/burger joint on this end of  Asian Avenue, read: Clement St (there is Q at the other side of 6th ave.) 

I had the English Light for brunch, trying to keep within my diet of low fat (HA!), which literally consisted of 2 poached eggs on toasted english muffins and a ham steak. Ham steak was good, poached eggs and muffin needed something, sauce perhaps?! I suppose "light" is bland and simple. My friend really enjoyed his Country Scramble smothered in gravy, however.

Food is good. Prices are standard. Portions are practical. Staff is nice. Cash only, atm is located by the door.
author: Deanna T.

description:
This is the kind of place that was probably once ubiquitous in San Francisco but whose clientele has slowly died off or left the city.  It would be nothing special in any Midwestern town, but in San Francisco, the old-fashioned burger place with '70s decorations is a dying breed.  The veggie burger I had here was good, and the service was very attentive.

If you're a food snob, you won't like this place.  If you moved to San Francisco in the last ten years, you probably won't like this place.  If you're older than seventy, you'll love this place.  It's a cross between the Lucky Penny and Whiz Burger, with a little bit of Tony's Cable Car Restaurant thrown in.
author: John S.

description:
Ultimately, it's really not about the food. I, for one, find it just a little heartbreaking to read all the reviews from people who just don't *get* the appeal of a place like hamburger haven. 

In my experience, it was a nice time capsule of a divey diner that definitely reminded me of places back home. My chicken sandwich was rather good and my fountain diet coke was perfect. So there.
author: jessica s.

description:
Burgers were not too bad, a tad dry but still somewhat tastey.

Milkshake was too runny, could of been thicker so it wouldnt feel like a ice cream drink.

Service was good. And the seats near the windows those little booths..you can actually adjust it so if you need more belly space..like me, then you can just push the chair back. Hard to explain but the waitress will explain if she notices you are having a difficult time eating.
author: phillip w.

description: It's your typical diner- greasy, inexpensive food.  I heard Robin Williams comes in here on occasion.  I got French Toast and tea and both seemed decent.  They have very reasonable specials with a ton of food on your plate.  I didn't try a burger here but if it's called Hamburger Haven, they must be good.  My friends always pick interesting restaurants.  There's plenty of street parking which is always a bonus, especially in this city.
author: Amy J.

description:
Dirty good. I love people's negative reviews here..Did you think you were walking into the Ritz Carlton dining room? Do you complain about wrinkled shirt from a thrift store?  You've got to know that once you walk in to The Haven you risk shaving a few weeks off your lifespan. 
When this place is gone we'll be sorry.
author: charles p fa t.

description:
When you just want a good f*in hamburger, you must go here. Delicious fries, fresh fixin's, and hot, juicy burgers-- all the basics done well. The service is great (the food comes fast and the owner is really sweet). Perhaps my favorite thing is that it's pretty quiet, like you can actually have a conversation. Sure, you may be the only people under 50 in there...but whatev, don't be ageist.

Down sides? Cash only and they close at 8:30pm, even on weekends.

Delightful when paired with a simple dessert of almond M&M's from the Walgreen's across the street.
author: RA D.

description:
I came here christmas eve around 11ish
Service was excellent!  The waiter was very helpful and friendly.
Food came out while HOT!!!
They have waffles!  Why aren't there more places with waffles?  
M-F breakfast special for $4.95 2 pancakes eggs and choice of bacon or sausage
Might I add that the hashbrowns were mighty tasty!!  And I don't care much for hashbrowns.  It was fried goodness.  Crispy edges with a nice soft potato insides.  Mmmm.....
I was impressed by this lil diner!  Definitely one of my favorite. I hope to go back soon!!!
author: Elisa O.

description:
A charming, old school diner.  Great breakfasts!  They get an extra star for having biscuits and gravy (my favorite) on the menu.  

I LOVE burgers too so I'll have to try one next time.
author: C C.

description: it's pretty much an average burger place. i had the teriyaki burger and it was alright. There was't anything i found specific about that burger that made it great, but in the end i was pretty much satisfied. theres more food i need to try just in case like their breakfast menu so i wouldn't mind coming back.
author: Henzley Z.

description:
Not bad. Came here for brunch today with a group of friends. Expect typical American style breakfast - pancakes, sausages (bacon... YUCK), eggs, omelets, etc. I had the biscuits and gravy.

For price and portion, Hamburger Haven isn't bad. Nice mom and pop place that's good for the whole family.
author: Teresa Y.

description:
Disclaimer: I've only eaten breakfast here.

This place makes me sad. I imagine it as once being a great place, offering good value. I so want it to be good, but it's not, it's not even decent. Hamburger Haven is terrible, not sure how they are still in business. It makes me think this place has changed ownership many times.

1) Service is horrible: I never thought outsourced call center service would have an equal. It does and you can find it at Hamburger Haven. The staff is clearly not happy about life.

Tip - don't even think about asking for something not on the script (egg whites, decaf, milk, lemon, hot water). It only leads to trouble.

2) The gravy (on the biscuits) is disgusting. 

3) Bacon is so thin it could be consider "diet bacon" or "bacon light"

4) It's expensive! Go somewhere else - much better value.

I've been here a few times and it only get worse each time. Yelp, can you add a stat for how many times a person has been somewhere when reviewing it? It makes a difference in the credibility of the review.
author: Judd L.

description:
Hamburger Haven, you are the father of New Danny's! 

This place is the bottom of the barrel cheap eats. How do places like these stay open?! Very hopeful, positive, naive patrons who want to eat  something else than Asian food. Clement is not the home of American food. 

Typical diner, you probably can make it better at home food. I don't know how the breakfast is but their lunch is GAH: Greasy as Hell! 

Weird, eerie ambiance. No renovations, small ass seats, old school decor, and very little chatter. Just overall odd vibe from this place. It feels haunted.  

My bf said to me before we ordered, "What do you think Chef Ramsey would say about this place?! I told him, "Please don't say that to me right now and gave him the "don't even go there" look.
author: Nikki N.

description:
I'm not about to complain about food quality if breakfast is $4.99. You get what you pay for. 

But, I do expect some decent math when it comes to my bill. My companion and I both ordered the $4.99 breakfast. What we weren't told was that the hash browns were another $1.95 extra. Fine, whatever. We'll count that as strike 1.

Even then, though, total+tax on 4.99 is not 5.50. Yeah, the difference is cents. But 6 cents to pay that is my discretion, not the store owner's. Strike 2.

Then we got overcharged for a milkshake. Probably an honest mistake too. But add it all up - 3 strikes, they're out.

They should use their cash register for their calculations, seriously. Instead of just as a glorified money box.
author: v w.

description:
This is a no-frills diner joint that I'd rather go to than Denny's.  They have burgers served with hot fries out of the fryer that are tasty and satisfies the starving stomach.  The wait staff are always nice and attentive to refiling your beverage and making sure everything is fine.

only caveat is that it closes so early and takes cash only, but heck, it's $8 for a hamburger, fries, and a coke.  You just can't complain.
author: Tim L.

description:
I used to come here every once in a while over the years, but today's breakfast was so bad I'll probably never be back.

The food was just plain awful.  The eggs, hash browns and sausages were  saturated in cooking oil that seemed old.  The toast was made out of stale, really cheap low quality wheat bread--the kind that costs 99 cents a loaf at Safeway..  

I just can't think of any reason to go there anymore.  If you're going to serve food this bad ($7.50 for a greasy, lame omelette), it should be dirt cheap, which it's not.    In the same price range, Hard Knox Cafe on Clement has tasty, creative breakfasts (grits, chicken apple sausage), and Joe's Coffee Shop is a better greasy spoon kind of place.

Not sure what happened, but I also suspected new management.  I can't put my finger on it, but there just seemed something off about the place's atmosphere.  It no longer seemed like an authentic old school diner.  It just seemed run down and indifferent.
author: Lawrence S.

description:
This place is a neighborhood favorite of mine. I love getting breakfast there, it's tasty, made well and cheap! My favorite is the eggs benedict with breakfast potatoes (done with onion and bell peppers) and fresh fruit (mind, their fresh fruit comes from a can). The coffee keeps coming, and they serve it with real cream. I've taken a few friends and family, and they've enjoyed pancakes, all styles of eggs, real milkshakes, etc.

It's good quality, fresh, made well, and local, though definitely on the greasy spoon side. I recommend it. If you're going with a group of 3 or more, it may be a bit of a wait. The front is all two-seater booths and counter, but there are larger tables in the back.
author: Diana G.

description:
It's like the current Asian owners bought the place from some Italians in the 1970's who were going out of business. The new owners were like "I like how this place looks, and kept it the same way." Make sure to sit in the back. 

When we were leaving the waitress asked my friend and I if we wanted anything else. My friend, said "do you have a cigarette?" They laughed and said no. As we were leaving the waitress ran out of Hamburger Haven and gave him a full pack of cigarettes for free. If that isn't service I don't know what is. 

The food is four stars. But the service is defiantly five.
author: F B.

description: The food is subpar and only fairly cheap, not cheap enough for the poor quality. Got the country breakfast. The eggs were rubbery and bland, the sausage was gross, and the gravy was a poor excuse for sauce. The server was unhelpful. Found a dry tasteless bay leaf in my eggs, could have done without that. Overall not great.
author: Spencer D.

description:
This is definitely not the best breakfast place in the city. With that being said, its just an OK place for breakfast.  If your only a few blocks away, hungover then the place gets even better. The food is standard American breakfast at a reasonable price. You can walk out of there with a gully filled with eggs, bacon pancakes and coffee for around $8.00. 
The help is always friendly. There are some nice Mexican bussers that are always more than willing to give you the "hair of the dog" if you mention the word beers. :) Unfortunately there are no Bloody Marys, just beers. 
I still haven't tried their non breakfast stuff but you can't go too wrong for what your get for your buck.
author: Ryan S.

description: I can't stop singing their praises! A great place to eat! I feel like family everytime we walk in. The waitress there is such a sweet heart!
author: Maya L.

description:
If you are looking for that realistic 1940' style place to dine?  Then Hamburger Haven is it.  The decor reminds you of a 1940 setting for a gangster movi or when the soldiers came back from WWII and squeezeed in there for a bite while waiting to depart..  The restaurant still has the same charm it might have back then.  

I have seen people call it a grease trap and under grade establishment.  But if you are a historian or someoe just liking the peaceful piece it offers.  Take a chance.

We go there to have chesseburgers.  Original I ran into the cafe to get out of the rain with my daughter.  I remember visiting that place once before years ago and the outstanding thing was the french fries then.  This time I had a tea party with my daughter.

The people running the place might have been there years ago also.  

Can I recommend it to someone? I believe that there are many tastes out there.  But Hamburger Haven can only cater to the one that remember what a hamburger is suppose to taste like, friendly help and a quiet place to eat.
author: China Doll B.

description:
I've been coming here since I was... 8? Seriously. I must of spent loads of dough on this joint in the past... Um, many years. Anyway, this a great breakfast and lunch spot. It is owned by a Persian couple who likes to hire Asian waitresses and Mexican/Filipino cooks. So that's your first plus; it is ethnically diverse. The owner is a goofy old man who waits in the mornings. You'll recognize him by his "Ecology and Me" apron. Very funny guy who'll joke with a straight face. The is a busboy/ evening cook (LOL) name Jose who'll refill your coffee and water as often as you like. Good staff. 

Menu includes pancakes, omelettes, bacon/sausages, eggs, and has brown for breakfast, burgers, fries, salads, and soup for lunch, spaghetti, hamburger steaks, and mashed pototaes for dinner. Actually, it doesn't matter because you can get any of the above at any hour of the day. The food is good but kind of greasy. If you're on the Special K diet, you might not want to stop here. Otherwise, try the Denver omelette, Veggie burger, and Spaghetti with meat sauce. 

It is a good neighborhood restaurant that's been around since the late 1970s/early 80s. Give it a try if you're in the area but don't go out of your way to make reservations (which they don't take anyway). 

FYI: opens at 7am, closes at 9pm.
author: Emily F.

description: I went in today with my BF for a quick American breakfast and that's exactly what we got. Food was great (I really liked the hash browns and bacon was nice + crispy) and the quantity was filling. The service was also prompt, friendly, and funny. I will definitely be back again soon!
author: Grace C.

description: This place is a really good old school burger joint.  It feels like a time warp except for the United Nations staff.  I'd eat there all the time for burgers if I could because the service and food are great.  Add this to my list of Reasons Why Clement Street Is That Awesome.
author: Mark W.

description: I've been meaning to write this review for a long time.  My mom and I were shopping on Clement and wanted to grab a quick lunch.  We sat at the counter and ordered 2 small salads and a tuna melt and a grilled cheese sandwich.  It was awful, greasy, food.  The salads were iceberg lettuce with rotting leaves mixed in and pink tomatoes and no flavor.  The cheese was low quality and the tuna was disgusting.  Place was dirty and plates had old food residue stuck on them.
author: Bret E.

description:
Ok... so the food is totally average, but I really love it here.  I mean the guy who runs it is funny and nice. You can't get to the bottom of your coffee cup without getting a top off.  And, it's cheap. 
cash only.
author: k g.

description:
Went back a second time and got their corned beef hash. mmm. They shape it into a patty (fits in with the whole hamburger thing) and it was delicious. Great crust on the outside and really good flavor. 

Coffee was good this time too. Plus they have hash browns which other places i've been frequenting do not have (other places have "country potatoes"). So definitely a big plus.

Not much else to say besides that, but I remember having written a review for it way back when and I didn't feel right leaving it at a 3... so wanted to at least update, cuz I'll definitley be back.
author: Bonnie H.

description:
Several months ago, before I started using Yelp, I went up to Green Apple  Books and a cold and foggy Sunday Morning. I get up to the Richmond and realize that I'm darn hungry. So I decide to find some place to grab a quick breakfast. After very little deliberation, I chose Hamburger Haven, mostly because it looked like the door was some sort of time travel device. 

The inside looks like it went through a few partial redecorations, but that was all stopped prior to 1980. It's a bit dingy and dark, but the staff was really friendly. And they have a counter, which is great for when you're eating alone. If only I had my camera with me that morning. 

The food was passable breakfast fare, omelet  and hash browns. The weakest part of the food was the canned peaches that came with my breakfast - no fruit would have probably been a less odd choice. The coffee was a bit weak, but hot and quickly filled.  The price was relatively low. I'm not sure if I'd necessarily go back, but I wouldn't avoid it.
author: neil c.

description:
I give 4.5 stars  to their breakfast menu. I have not eaten from their dinner menu so I have no comment on that...

Yummy diner breakfast, very nice service, no wait on a Saturday morning at 10am. 

They do not take cards which irritates me and takes .5 away from them. Other than that this place has a killer eggs benedict...
author: Emily H.

description: it seems so old fashioned but I don't know, I don't feel really welcomed there. my family ate there but we felt it was a little pricey for the food. the service was alright but I cant say I would go back... :-/ the food was okay
author: Debby D.

description:
Shocking how good the coffee is here.
They made us chili cheese fries, even if it wasn't on the menu.
The peach pie is surprisingly delicious.
Bizarre Middle America-looking diner staffed by Asian Americans. Awesome.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Oh the good ol' Hamburger Haven.  
This is a great little greasy-spoon breakfast joint.  I'm pretty much a Saturday afternoon regular since it's so close to home and they serve breakfast until 3.  This is a good place to go when you need stick-to-your-ribs after-party food.  The menu is pretty basic,  but the waitresses are nice and the food comes out fast.  The coffee kinda sucks but the refills never end.  Two people can dine for about $15.  Three stars for consistency,  friendliness, and affordability.

(Puh-leease! to those reviewers who have complained about cleanliness.  I have dined at HH many a time during daylight hours- meaning you could see everything including dirt.  Old decor doesn't just make a place dirty, ya know?  Also, I have used their restroom and I'd say it's pretty damn clean.  As clean as any other restaurant in the City.  Stop being a germaphobe.)
author: Natalie B.

description:
I came here having high expectations -perhaps because it SO had the possibility of being a terrific dive. 

I was a bit frightened by the 'open grill' as I could see everything (and preferred not to.) The boy got a burger - which did not seem to be made with fresh ground beef (sad day, really.) He said it was OK. I ordered a hot dog - and asked for fried onions (50 cents surcharge... well worth it.) The hot dog was great - and the fries we got were pretty crispy.

I'll give the place 2 stars - 1 for price & 1 for a great dog.

Minus 3 for: mediocre burger (fresh patty - please?, only 2 beer choices -bud & bud light, & the fly I found swimming in my water.) Hey - the fly was an accident I'm sure.

I am curious to try breakfast here.
author: Jessica M.

description:
Hamburger Haven is an oldie but a goodie. It's on the corner of 9th and Clement, and has a framed photo of the staff with Robin Williams proudly displayed in the window.
HH is cash only (I think, not sure). I've been here for lunch once or twice, okay, nothing special, and for breakfast a few times. The food is your standard diner food, but the staff is very nice and accommodating.
I came in and ordered decaf coffee, and they had to make a fresh pot for me. The rest of the time I was there they kept coming by to give me more coffee, joking that I'd have to drink the whole pot.
It seems like there are a lot of regulars here, which is comforting.
author: Rachel M.

description:
The only reason I am deducting a star is that the waiters are really awkward. The prices are great -- my roommate and I both had the wonderful Eggs Florentine, and they came with delicious potatoes (with the offer of substituting hash browns) and two peach halves swimming in syrup. The orange juice was also really amazing.

The awkwardness came at the end, when, after leaving a pretty standard tip, the waiter shook our money back at us and said, "THANK YOU, girls! You made my day! You really made my whole day!" This left us asking ourselves, "do they think we're annoying rich girls who just throw money left and right? Because I'm pretty broke..." and it just lead to a series of questions that I didn't want to consider at 9am.
author: Jordan S.

description:
Average diner-style food, but the guy behind the counter is a crack up. I went in with my friend Guy Spanali from Rattlecans, who is also my neighbor, to order some breakfast, and when I decided to get the French Toast, he exclaimed, "Oh, yes, the French Toast! That's a good item, a very good item", like it was the best ever. My friend and I couldn't stop cracking up, and so we've kinda made this spot a semi-regular breakfy stop on his Tuesdays off from work. The latino busboy is very nice and friendly, and refills the coffee and water in a most efficient and pleasant manner. The chick at the cash register has seen me/us in there a zillion times, and still treats it as if she's never met either of us, or at most, with studied indifference. 

That aside, there is a pretty good meal deal where it's possible to get eggs, bacon and toast or pancakes for $3.99--but get there before 10:00 am (I think that's the cutoff) or the deal is off--and forget it if it's a weekend. Still if I'm up early, and my buddy is into it, I'll go. What the heck--it's cheap, and can be entertaining.
author: ACE A.

description: This place was the worst cafe/burger joint I have ever been to. The service was horrid and the food tasted like something they bought from the day old taco truck.
author: Nelson H.

description: We went for the breakfast because I heard it was good and I need to expand my choices. It's a greasy spoon, but a good one. I'd say its slightly better than bashful bull, which happens to be a favorite of mine. The food was all good, and the service friendly. It depends on what you want to spend, right? The cost fits the food and it was good greasy spoon grub. The coffee, well, it was pretty bad. Even by "g.s" standards. If I lived nearby, I'd go back, but will probably go back to bashful bull next time. Not worth paying the meter for this place and at least I get to walk on the beach afterwards.
author: Rich M.

description:
This place has stayed the same for the 30+ years I've been going. I used to work at the Front Room, which was across the street. Real simple menu done excellent. It may be the only American food on Clement. 

This place is a hole in the wall, but efficiently run. The toast is actually toasted. The hash browns are browned. I haven't had a burger here more than maybe twice (and it was good) but I will recommend the breakfasts. And the sweet, cute waitress who served me.
author: Aaron B.

description:
I live in the neighborhood and love to go here for breakfast. You get a decent breakfast for under $5. If you want old coffee shop feel - go to Hamburger Haven. Service is fast and friendly. There are a lot of regulars making it so that you want to be a regular too. 

We also tried Hamburger Haven for dinner once when we were craving some home cooking. I got the chicken cutlet ($10.95), my friend got the spaghetti and meat balls ($6.95) and my boyfriend got the club house ($6.95) all to go so we could enjoy our home cookin' at home. We were all happy with our dinners although my cutlet was a little bland. 

Remember to bring cash since they only accept cash and no cards.
author: Wendy B.

description: came here for breakfast with my little family (me, hubby, 3 kids) about a month or so ago. we were in search for a local breakfast spot. decent priced menu. small place, i cant imagine how they could accommodate a large party. our waitress was friendly, food was good-. its a good place to go for a simple breakfast, nothing fancy. will definitely come again on the days i don't feel like making my own breakfast at home.
author: Denise L.

description: I can only assume the snide comments about Hamburger Haven are submitted by spoiled middle class brats newly arrived in town from the 'burbs (or Orange County) who are in love with their own ersatz sophistication and "cool."  Hamburger Haven is the quintessential greasy spoon run by a super nice Iranian family and has been on the corner of Ninth and Clement forever.  Its not for trendoids or self-styled "foodies."  It's for those who are looking for  greasy comfort food served by friendly people and heavily populated by regular customers.  I don't eat meat any more, but when I did I went there for what I considered the best club sandwich in town.  Back then it featured real sliced-off-the-breast turkey.
author: Nancy I.

description:
Tonight I was driving down Clement with the family looking for a restaurant.  Normally we'd eat at Georgio's but we'd just been there on Saturday.  We were looking for something that wasn't pizza.  We spotted Hamburger Haven.  Yes, hamburgers and fries would hit the spot.  We parked.

As soon as we walked inside, I had second thoughts.  The place looked like it hadn't been updated since the 70s, the walls next to the booth we sat in were dirty, and it looked like the few patrons inside were eating pancakes, bacon, and eggs.  At 7:30 pm on a Monday.  Could this be a good sign for a place called Hamburger Haven?

Fortunately they have a back room that sits parties of 2 or more.  The waitress flipped on the light back there.  We had the whole room to ourselves (a good thing since our 4 year old was being particularly rambunctious) but it was FREEZING cold.  None of us took our coats off the entire meal.

But... NO HIGHCHAIRS.  Huh??!  And... why??!  The husband and I had to take turns holding the 10.5 month old princess.

Not wanting breakfast food, we took a chance and ordered items from the dinner menu.  I ordered a cheeseburger with coleslaw and iced tea, the husband ordered a cheeseburger with onion rings and Coke, and our 4 year old ordered a hot dog with french fries and milk.

I'm glad we didn't chicken out because I was pleasantly surprised by the food.  Our cheeseburgers were very good.  I love how they slightly toast the bun.  The onion rings were very good and that's saying something because most places can't get them right.  And the french fries were damn near perfect: Crispy on the outside and soft on the inside.

I noticed that their milk shakes are only $3.95 (!!!) so we ordered a chocolate shake.  It tasted exactly like a homemade milkshake, i.e. made with chocolate ice cream and milk, not vanilla ice cream and chocolate syrup.  BIG thumbs up!

The waitress was attentive, refilling our drinks when necessary and didn't make us wait on the check which is a big pet peeve of mine.  Our entire check came to $31 and some change.

Great food for a diner.  Minus two stars for the creepy dirty 70s atmosphere and lack of highchairs.

All in all, I can't say we'd ever make a special trip to the Inner Richmond to go to Hamburger Haven but we'll probably stop by again when we're in the neighborhood.
author: Lori R.

description: Good ol' americana food. Breakfast is ok for the money.  Hash browns are decent. I like to sit at the counter and hear my eggs sizzle on the huge griddle.Also, good place to read the sunday paper by the window. Smack dab in da richmond with an eclectic array of shops and eateries. Go here during the weekday , visit the amazing -has everything - Ace Hardware store on 10th/clement, and for lunch cruise by the Ocean Chinese restaurant for a tastey Mojarra Pescado or Haigs for spankin' good falafel sando's. Take it all In with a Cold One.
author: Bert K.

description:
I've passed this place a zillion times over the years but never popped in.  I guess that visually, the place is just nothing special.  We finally decided to stop for their $5 breakfast special today- 2 eggs, 2 sausages (or bacon), 2 pancakes (or french toast).  

The food arrived quickly which is VERY important in my book, for weekday breakfast.  The service was friendly and coffee was refilled QUICKLY.  The place is also quite clean. 

Overall, food was average...but eggs are eggs, right?  I would recommend this place over Mel's Diner for weekdays!  If you want the good stuff on a lazy Sunday, drive over to Fred's in Sausalito!
author: Judy K.

description: Super cute place! I have had their breakfast and it was fantastic - huge portion for the price. Great service as well. CASH ONLY!
author: Stephanie F.

description: Relax people, this is not meant to be fine dining. This is a place owned and operated by a very nice family that obviously has pride in their restaurant . We have had wonderful service and great food every time we have gone in. Really great breakfasts and hamburgers. Give it a try!
author: Carol G.

description:
I seek out places that fit this description and decor. When I walked in, I was pretty excited to see orange tile and wood panel walls. Then everything went a little sour.  Got a couple of burgers and it cost $20.  For two diner burgers! A bit disapointing. The service was nice, but really nothing worth mentioning.  The food was nothing special at all. 

The charm of a great american greasy spoon diner is the cuisine...the unique way each of the greasy places makes their not so unique meals, unique. A burger that is simple, but delicious, and this one, not so delicious.  Hamburger haven, more like hamburger boring.

If the food costs about half of what it currently costs, this place would be a find.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
Perhaps I stepped in on an off day, but I surely wasn't in any place resembling a haven. What needed saving was the poor waitress. She was a bit flustered, attempting to assemble orders as the cook tried to put together his orders as quickly as possible.

It seems like everyone was waiting for their food to be assembled and delivered. It was the lunchtime rush, but wouldn't it be nice to have more than one waitress during these peak hours? 

The food was typical. I only had a grilled cheese and my friend had a cheeseburger, which he enjoyed. With just-average food, you would expect some better service, especially in a neighborhood like the Richmond. Guess not.
author: Bryan B.

description:
My busboy finished my toast for me here, then asked me to get grape jelly next time because he doesn't like strawberry.  He didn't sit down at the table or anything, he just slathered on the jelly and ate it while clearing the table.  And for some bizarre reason it was okay.  I hate to see food go to waste, anyway.

Having said that, I have to admit I've never had a hamburger here, but the place is a haven for your standard, inexpensive breakfast and friendly service.  Yes, it's a time capsule but I find it warm and comforting, especially on a cold and rainy day.  One caveat:  the grease factor is high.  A friend and I went one morning after a night of irresponsible living and were both pretty sorry after gobbling down big breakfasts.  The hash browns (shredded) are great - I get them well done, mmm, crispy outside, kinda mushy inside. . . Pancakes here are really good, too.  I recommend it if you want somewhere warm, friendly and quiet and aren't looking for anything stellar in the way of food, just something basic.
author: J B.

description:
good food, good sevice. 
Over all not bad
author: Robert B. D.

description: Though the weekday morning breakfast special is cheap and delicious (*Homer Simpson drooling noise* the way those greasy links feel and taste as you bite into them...), if for nothing else, I love seeing Monique there.  She's the sweetest server who, even in spite of gaps of months or years between visits, still remembers my mom, friend, and me.  When she's not there, I almost feel like it's an HH trip wasted, because the boss lady is pretty cold.  When she's your server, you're reminded of the days you had the audacity to show up to the dinner table after pissing your mother off, as you sit there with your head hung in shame, and she practically tosses the dishes on the table.
author: Jenn C.

description: If you live in this area this is definitely the place to pick for a good burger. I went here for the first time the other week and was very impressed. It's a little hole in the wall diner, so don't expect much inside the place, but they make a tasty tasty burger. The burger wasn't gigantic but just the right size for a hungry appetite. The meat was juicy and tender and the meal was decently priced. The service was exceptional and the atmosphere was really homey. It reminded me of my Grandfather's restaurant back in Nebraska, which is good. There's really not much more to say about it. If you want a good burger, check it out.
author: Ryan C.

description: First of all you don't go to Hamburger Haven for the gourmet food or ambiance, you go for good old country style breakfast and waitresses that remember you. Breakfast is definitely the best meal here. Things to go with are the Country Breakfast with eggs, bacon, sausage and biscuits and gravy or something with country potatoes. I'm a huge fan of eggs Benedict, but keep in mind their hollandaise is not top shelf. I usually get poached eggs which come out great and their sourdough toast is good. This place is a neighborhood institution and stays around because it doesn't put on airs or pretend to be some gourmet breakfast joint. It's great for rolling in at noon on a Saturday to read the paper, eat some food, and drink some coffee while dealing with that Friday evening headache.
author: Rebecca D.

description:
Ate at Hamburger Haven today for the first time in 15 years or so. This place is exactly the same as I remember it from 1994...and it goes back a lot longer than that.

It is what it is. A homey, welcoming diner. Breakfast is greasy spoon diner food, in a friendly neighborhood spot.

The "Joe's Special" breakfast is timeless.
author: R v.

description:
I come here often for brunch. It's a hole in the wall diner, and it's pretty cool with it's vintage decor. 

The service speed can vary depending how busy the place is, and I usually see the same short order cook working behind the counter. If you ever sit at the counter, you should watch him cook. When he makes about 10 orders at a time, it's a bit of an art form that you will never see at McDonalds or Burger King.
author: Daria M.

description: If comfort diner food is what you're looking for, then you can't go wrong with this place. I initially overlooked this restaurant as a breakfast spot because of its Hamburger Haven name. You'll get a decent no frills breakfast without the long lines at some of the other trendy weekend spots.  Yes, the eggs and coffee could be better but this place is a throwback to the diner days of yesteryear, and I've never had to wait for a table here.
author: LA J.

description:
This place has the best short order chef I have ever seen.  He works the grill and skillets like a piano player.  This Mozart-esque fellow behind the grill puts all other short order chefs to shame.

Please note: Sit at the counter and follow his every move.  From what I have heard this guy is on a 5 year contract from over seas, and there is already a bidding war going on between his future employers (Ella's and the Elite Cafe).

Also, the proprietors are an enchanting couple.  The wife is as sweet and as kind as your mother could ever be and the husband is known to give Robin Williams tips on comedy.
author: j.HiZZle l.

description: I recently moved into the Inner Richmond and while scoping out all the places on Clement, the 4.99 breakfast special was definitely enticing.  Sure enough, one hungover morning I peeled myself from bed, knowing exactly where I was going to trudge toward.  There's a special charm and familiar nostalgia at Hamburger Haven.  The service is always really friendly, and the owner is absolutely hilarious with his deadpan humor.  From the old school register, to the 1.25 bottomless coffee, the brown tile work, and the stools filled with regulars (which my boyfriend and I are quickly becoming) this place is really a gem.  The food good; go there for breakfast, read a paper, down some coffee, people watch, and enjoy!
author: Kasia P.

description: The service, fair. The decor, quaint. The food, old fashioned charm. OLD being the word of choice. The cook has no  idea what corned beef and hash is like, and if living dangerously is exciting, go ahead and try it. The cooks use deep fried discs of deep fried dog food for corned beef. Eat the caged eggs, eat the cheap toast, drink the metalic tasting coffee, enjoy the card board flavored waffles, but don't treat your life cheaply by eating the corned beef hash. If a cook from Hamburger Haven actually reads and cares about reviews from Yelp, I beg you to stop poisoning your customers with something YOU THINK is corned beef hash.
author: Brian J.

description: You want a nice greasy meal? This is the place to come and get one. Breakfast was good. The only thing that bothered me was my breakfast came 5 minutes before my boyfriend's breakfast did. So, of course I waited like a nice civilized girlfriend and stared at my hot steamy hashbrowns while they turned  to just hot. Finally, he got his pancakes. After that...it was all good. I guess you can say, it's a fancy Denny's with a friendlier wait staff.
author: Liz K.

description: I've been going to this place for the longest time.  Yes, the decor is dated, but the early bird special keep me coming back.  I'm a sucka for cheap n good food.  Where else can you get two eggs, pancakes  and sausages for $3.99??
author: hello k.

description: 70's kitsch makes me happy! So, Hamburger Haven offers me a great field trip back to a special place in time. I have only done lunch but I like their veggie burger- it is decent. Try it if your into kitschy diner if not then skip it.
author: Shannon Z.

description:
I wouldn't even give it a one star but it wouldn't post if Ididn't pick one star at min.  Are you insane...all of these reviews? Is these reviews done by the family of this place? We went today....my son is here visiting. "Robin Williams loves this place". What is the 70's? Lets start with the decor...greasy stained carpets with smoke from the 80's and green and yellow/orange window pains which advertise a fun "happy Hours available" sign . 
The food though is most important..."Patty Melt to die for...": That's true...that is accurate ...I feel like I am going to die after trying to be a good sport for my son. This place is Hamburger Hell. Who in the heck goes to a place like this and writes a review that encourages people to get in their car and try to digest the horse meat that is this place. It should be torn down, run over by the Go Cars that are all over sanFrancisco. Not to mention nobody speaks English in this place. Pissed
author: Kimberly T.

description: I love this place!! The wait staff here treat me like a king! Very friendly and food is pretty good
author: T S.

description:
I loved this place. I ordered the "California" burger- done medium well, with onions, tomatoes, lettuce, fresh avocado, bacon and jack cheese. The french fries were done perfectly- golden brown and not-too-salty. 

I got take out, but if you want to eat in there's a number of small booths and a long bar to sit at where you can watch the cooks grill up your order. Has a very 50s atmosphere with trinkets and period photos on the wall. Very cozy. 

Reasonably priced and good-sized portions make this a worthwhile stop if you're hungry for some good tasting American grub on Clement Ave.
author: Alex G.

description: I have been going to this place for years now. The setting is very relaxed and the way I describe it is my favorite local diner. The decor isn't flashy or modern. It's a very quaint and comfortable setting. The owner is very friendly and knows my mom's, sister's, and my regular order by heart. My mom loves the Joe's Special and home potatoes. Sis usually gets the Joe's Special or a Mushroom omelette with cheese. I usually get the mushroom omelette with cheese with hash browns or the french toast, sausage, and eggs, which is on the breakfast special for about $6. For lunch I'll have a mushroom burger with bacon and cheddar or American cheese.
author: Tanyamarie A.

description: I go to Hamburger Haven often!  The food is usually good, but sometimes can be inconsistent!  I go for breakfast which is usually delicious!  Depending on how busy the cook is, my eggs can sometimes be overdone, but usually good food at reasonable prices.  Judy is my favorite waitress there.  She's always attentive and friendly.  HH is a great neighborhood diner to frequent for good food!!!
author: Stephanie A.

description: I'm an East Coast lady through and through and nothing warms my heart more than a good old fashioned diner serving low brow american favorites with booths and a loooong counter. Not as good as Bill's Place and unfortunately cash only, but if you're down on Clement and not in the mood for Asian food, you could do far worse than the Haven.
author: Maria D.

description: Why the hell is the name of this restuarant made plural ?(Restaurants)  This is one of the many problems with this place.  First off it was dirty, gritty, grimmy, and just nasty.  I asked for a glass of water and received something some semi-clear liquid in a frosted glass.  The glass was not manufactured to be frosted!  This place is not a haven for Hamburgers but rather a haven for just nastiness.  Let me just add that I'm a huge fan of dives.  But this one was off the deep end.
author: Josh G.

description:
*edit -
  I would be remiss if I did not mention they have recently raised their prices. While some of their food is still good, most of it is not quite worth the charge. I ordered fish and chips and got two tiny Gordon's frozen patty quality pieces of fish. At $8, the quality was not worth the price and I was still hungry after. 
  Their steak and their breakfast are still good food at a decent price. But if I wanted a sandwich or a burger, there are more than a couple of places I would go before here. Below, I have left my original review.

First, I stop at a newspaper box and grab the daily. I walk in, sit down, and before I have even settled in, I have an Iced Tea on my table set down by a smiling face. If I go by myself, she asks where the boy is.
 It is always a hard decision to make - breakfast or lunch. The breakfast is the best for your buck. Large portions of pancakes, hash, biscuits and gravy, but I am partial to the Eggs Florentine. But the burger is a very decent diner burger and only $4.95. $5.45 for a cheeseburger. 
 When one day the boy decided he wanted steak, I was wary. Small diners are not known for their choice cuts of meat or for they way they cook them, but I had no reason to worry. Of course it was not 5 star steakhouse quality, but it was darn good, and only $11.  I have not had bad food here yet.
 The place is not super cool, or hip, or a hotspot. It is cozy in the old diner way, lots of browns and other 70's earth tones. There is a counter to sit at, small booths, and a back area with larger booths and tables. 
 4 stars for being exactly what it says it is, for personable and neighborly service, for being the best deal for your dollar, for being a cozy place to sit for long periods with the crossword and the comics, a
author: Miss Kae O.

description: Great place. Love the old-original-diner atmosphere. Was also really surprised at how clean it was. Friendly-efficient staff. Love it. Went with the traditional cheeseburger and fries cooked medium--with a coke. It came out medium and the fries were nice and crispy. A simple burger executed perfectly.
author: Boo R.

description: Okay.. It's a diner... but if you ever accidentally wake up in the Richmond, might I recommend Hamburger Haven. Shhhhhh, it's okay, look at those hash browns!
author: katharine s.

description: This is one of the great finds in San Francisco for breakfast. I grew up in New York and this reminds me of my favorite diner...They do it all and do it very well. Lunch is great too...My breakfast favs are the French toast, eggs benedict, corned beef hash...Yum...Never a wait and always good..Its owned by two wonderful people...Majid and Monique. Check it out sometime. You won't be disappointed.
author: Michael M.

description: This place is my favorite find so far in San Francisco. Don't go there for retro kitsch -- they don't have it. Have a hamburger and some fries. They always make it just right! And if you go in the evenings on weeknights, you'll meet my favorite waitress. She's gentle and nice, and she remembers my drink order. Hamburger Haven is a great place to chill with a friend. It's too bad they close at 9 pm.
author: Vanessa N.

description: This place is solid. However, it is not often busy, and the competition (new place, Stein's across the street) is POUNDING the living day lights of this place. However, the ambiance is very old-timey, and the food is pretty good. Not the best burger I've ever had, but not the worst by any means. Has the California Bacon burger... pretty good, I must admit. Will come here, but not a top priority.
author: Samantha W.

description: For locals only.  I used to get the breakfast special for like $2.95 for two egss, bacon, toast, coffee and ham, or something ridiculous like that.  It's gone up to $3.95.  Anyway, a great value.  Good burgers.
author: Pug P.

description:
Stopped by last week for breakfast.  Corned beef hash, hash browns, eggs and toast.  I used to drop by just for burgers, and recently found that they serve breakfast too!

The place was full - mostly family and couples, but no long wait.  Everyone appeared to be enjoying their food.  I found the ingredients to be fresh, servings well proportioned, and service excellent.

A diner with a good family atmosphere.  Conversation was easy,  coffee refilled without asking, wait persons stopped by several times to make sure all was OK.
author: Antonio E.

description: They should have called this place Breakfast Haven because their burgers are not as good as their burgers. Service is kind of crappy even when you sit at the bar. It might have been a single incident so I don't know.
author: Darius A.

description: Old school breakfast....no frills...family owned and operated...for a long time..good service...
author: Liz D.

description: VERY DIRTY.   Two out of three glasses of water ordered by my table came with sweater fuzz, hairs, dust, food specks, and other debris of unknown origin.  I got a veggie omelet - the veggies were cooked in so much grease that as I cut the omelet open, oil literally poured out of my omelet.  There was crusty food from the last customer - or maybe last week - on the table.  At least the food was served piping hot - I think that may have killed the germs as it has been about 8 hours since my meal, and unlike other yelpers, I don't have a tummy ache - yet...  :)
author: Cara C.

description: *sigh* okay so i've been coming to this place for a ruben burger for the past couple of years. i went there again recently and boy was i disappointed! I'm guessing that they changed owners and the whole menu changed. The ruben burger didn't make the cut so i went for a mushroom burger. to my surprise, the patty was just like the ones you get at mcdonalds. it's so sad to say that i'm most likely not going to come back here to get my burger fix.
author: Lynn P.

description: There is a special place in my heart for Hamburger Haven. It's not fancy, nor expensive. It is the restaurant that you fall in love with when you just want some simple and good comfort food.
author: Judy L.

description: This has been to me and my girlfriend one of the best places to get a Bacon Cheese Burger. I like to order my Bacon Cheese Burger with mustard ketchup hold the mayonnaise lettuce tomatoes onion and pickles i think it adds flavor. I'm not too sure about the breakfast or anything elce but burgers A+
author: The Food Hunters C.

description:
I've heard some pretty gross stories about the lack of cleanliness, but I haven't witnessed it myself yet. I dont care to find out. The prices are reasonable and the food is good. Overall, they need to work on cleaning it up and possibly getting some new furniture.

I've taken some of my "kids" here [I mentor kids.] and one of them found a bug in her water. I've heard other stories, but they are just stories. I cannot prove them factual, but I will say this is a local's spot.

It has a very friendly, neighborhood vibe. Nothing fancy. nothing special.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~
to update. I just had breakfast with my mom here. Service wasn't great, but decent. Not necessarily attentative. They have a great $4.99 deal on week days before 11am. Again, it's what I consider a "locals" place to dine. The food was good. Nothing special. And, no, we didn't find any bugs or dirty dishes.

------
Alright so I have to admit that I keep coming back here. It's just one of those local's Pisces to go for breakfast.
author: nightlife i.

description: I love Hamburger Haven.  The name brought me in, the coffee gave me a semi.  Too much?  I'm sorry, but the coffee is surprisingly delicious here, and the French Toast is tasty, too.  Bring cash, though.  There have been a few hungover mornings when I had to walk down to the ATM to pay for breaky.    Service is friendly and attentive.  Haven't had a burger here, though I hear good things.
author: Geoff M.

description: Walking into Hamburger Haven is like stepping into a time warp right back to the 50's. The food is typical diner fare (yum!) and features the free salad bar with order. The salad bar features iceberg lettuce, tomatoes, beets, and croutons but what more do you need? Great place for breakfast, lunch, or dinner. The shakes are a bit subpar and they only take cash but there is an ATM across the street. Super burgers and frys.
author: Colin S.

description: I like sitting at the bar and watching the multitasking cook. The best breakfast deal is the Hotcake Sandwich, but you gotta get there before 11 am. The food isn't spectacular, but it's always a good place to go the morning after a fun night. Plus, I always meet interesting characters there, always. But I'm not sure what they put in the coffee, if you get me...
author: Roman H.

description: I love places that serves food with open kitchens! Since I like looking at people cooking food! I came here with my boyfriend I got a hamburger with fries. It was quite normal. Their fries are CHEAPER here then Quicklys. My boyfriend used to come here with his grandpa, but he passed away, his elementary classmate's family used to own the place, but they sold it. The waiter was really friendly.
author: Janet Z.

description:
I've been living a block from this place for over three years but only started going there a few months ago. It always seemed kind of creepy or depressing but after trying it once, I'm now addicted to it's classic diner charm.  

I get the same thing every time, their breakfast special. It's only $4.95 before 11am and $5.95 after: Two pancakes, two eggs and two bacon.  The bacon could be a little better but overall, it's a good meal.  I also add toast and tea and the tab is under $10.  I always tip well because the service is GREAT.  Even the busboy is super friendly and helpful.  And I like the retro vibe and the two pics of Robin Williams on the wall.  I asked them if he still goes in there and they said like every 6 months or so and he always orders the same thing but I can't remember what it was. 

Oh yea, I ate the exact same meal at Denny's on Mission and 4th a few days ago and I like HH's version better.  Denny's pancakes were chewy and gross.  HH has better service too.
author: Mike A.

description:
on the way back to elsie's place from eating at bills (best burgers in my opinion) this old man with a walker just started talking-yelling to us.  "i'ma goin' to hamburger haven down on cle-ment street. they use real beef, and have great prices." -in your best old man voice

this was a spectacle, seeing as we were on 35th ave and he was talking about going to 9th or something. kinda crazy as he was using a walker.

i got a blt and a burger from here.  it wasn't as good as bills.
author: Ameer N.

description:
the best hangover turkey burger (4 stars), but bad service (minus one star).  there's a busboy that's super nice, but the waitservice not so much. 

they get an extra star for being close enough to stumble to.  nets out to 4 stars.  that's the math lesson for today.

oh!! and there's never a wait on sunday mornings.  you won't find any yuppy brunch peeps at ths hole in the wall (7 extra stars - i just mucked up the math lesson).
author: jen b.

description: They are open by 8am, when Clement Street is still waking up, and Q and Clement Street B&G are still dark.  It's not as good as Tennessee Grill, but it isn't half bad if you don't feel like crossing the Park.
author: K W.

description: I end up here for breakfast almost every weekend. I really do like the food here. The burgers are great, the breakfast is awesome. They have the strangest salad dressings, like they're mixed together. I love the "blue cheese" which is more like ranch with blue cheese crumbles in it. The fries are good, the grilled cheese on rye is great! I don't think I've ever had anything that was bad.
author: Joy T.

description:
$3.99 breakfast...lunch for under $10 AND it is consistently good!  Best bargain food in the city!

I've been going for 10 years and have yet to see a different cook, and watching him is something to behold!  He is amazing whether they are busy or slow...he truly is a "grill master".  Love the wait staff, although more so once I became a regular.

Old booth and counter seating (some tables)...feels like you are transported back in time (and not cliche like Mel's - this is seriously old school).  

I typically go for breakfast, but when I am in the mood for a burger it is one of the first places I think of!
author: Theresa S.

description: If you live in the Richmond you've most likely eaten here. I have several times. Omelette's are okay. Burgers only fair. Service has been good. Nothing special really, not worth a trip unless you happen to be in the neighborhood.
author: chris m.

description:
its greasy! its quick! its cheap!

brunch here is alright.  i like the price and the homey feel of the place.  the one thing that keeps me going is the coffee service.  the refills are quick and plentiful.  you never have an empty cup.
author: Lucy M.

description: I work straight accross the road.  Won't say where.  But this place is always quietly turning over.  I think this place as I see it, makes quite a fair bit of cash.  Overhead looks low, continously busy.  People consistently coming and going.  The place isn't much to look at.  And the food is your standard american grill.  I like this place.  The owner is a freindly guy.  Very respectful.  Great place if you need a place to read the paper.
author: Nick T.

description:
Not satisfying at all. I ordered a middle-eastern style burger, thinking it would get me something with nice exotic spices. Instead it just meant there were some onions in the burger, which is not a bad idea on its own. Unfortunately, the fries were not tasty, and the meat was quite flavourless as well. I ordered it medium rare and got it quite rare. I would even except that but the bun was all bloody which didnt make it any more appetizing..
It looks like they do a cheap breakfast but for a burger, I would go elsewhere.
author: rene p.

description: This place is dank, simple, cheap and chill. Good food, open kitchen, great prices. Holla.
author: Charles G.

description:
I will agree with other yelpers who say that this place is a little pricey for what you get.  But the service is always fast.  I work next door and have 30 minute lunch break.  I make it back with 10 minutes to spare.  

The service is always SUPER friendly!  Always a smile, and even when it's busy they'll still manage to have a chat with you.  

Food is about par for diner food.  Nothing very exciting.  My favorite item I've had here is their Club House Sandwich.  

Overall my favorite part about this place is the comfort of walking in knowing I'll get a quick meal with good service.
author: Travis W.

description:
got a california burger.
patty was big, bacon was tasteless as was the cheese.
came with lettuce, tomato, avocado and onion

potato salad was of safeway market quality. hamburgers were of cafeteria quality. somehow a produce sticker ended up in my burger and i almost ate it. 

friendly service, but not coming back.
author: Porkers T.

description: When I'm yearning for a home cooked meal and don't, ok I'll be honest-can't do it myself then I go to HH.  It's consistent and filling and a splurge if you eat healthy on a regular basis but have a craving that only saturated fat can can satiate.
author: Misti L.

description: In a city where it seems like everyone just goes from trendy restaurant to the next trendy restaurant, (I'm looking at you Dosa, NOPA and SPQR!) I always love finding a place like Hamburger Haven. It's no frills, completely untrendy, good food and down home atmosphere. I love how the menu proudly proclaims they've been around since 1968 and I plan on becoming a regular so they can stay open. I of course got the hamburger (how could you not at a place called Hamburger Haven?) and it did not disappoint. It was a simple and classic hamburger on a bun with lettuce, tomato and onion. It was juicy, flavorful and delicious. You get your choice of salad, potato salad or french fries and I got the fries which were nice and crispy, what more could you want from a fry? We also shared a vanilla milkshake which the waitress was nice enough to split into two mugs for us. The service here is great too, the waitress was super friendly and attentive and the food comes nice and fast. It looks like they've got some good deals for breakfast so I can't wait to come back and try them.
author: Cathy T.

description: God I love this place.  They really know how to make a hamburger.  This isn't any MacDonald's crap, it's a real hamburger made of real meat on a real bun (or roll).  Makes my mouth water just thinking about it.  And it's cheap!  The decor is outdated and the flowers are fake, but somehow that just adds to the charm of the place--especially the old time San Francisco photos.
author: Zannie A.

description:
Another overrated burger place in SF.  How could this be on anybody's "Best of  " list???  Sorry Guardian - you  don't know burgers.  My first trip here a month ago I had the 4.99 breakfast social and it was really good and a great value.  So, I went back for dinner.  UGH!  I tried the hamburger steak - get a good sense of the quality of the beef.  GREASY, and some unedible stringy things in it, too.  The fries were nothing special at all.  Cheese couldn't have improved them.  I had a salad.  ha ha  The veggies on the plate were either canned or were frozen then steamed tasteless so they would seem like canned.  
Here's what's worse!!! Only two kinds of beer - Bud Lite and Miller Lite - bottled.  What's that tell you???  At least they served it with a warm, thick-glass mug so it would quickly drain out any cold that was left in the beer.
I didn't mean to be so negative, but the more I think about it, well .....
I will do breakfast again.  Stay with Burgermeister, Frankie's on Divis.  Even Joe's Cable Car, though it's too expensive, is a better buy.
author: Bob M.

description: classic spot for breakfast or bugers. great service, good food.
author: Pflip W.

description: Best bang for your buck breakfast in The Richmond.  Burgers are decent, as are the sandwiches.  I had dinner here once and was not impressed. The meatloaf was surprisingly good (for $7), but the mashed potatoes tasted like instant and the veggies were frozen instead of fresh.  Service is very good and they are friendly folks.
author: Scott K.

description: surprisingly delicious hamburger, we call this place burger heaven. possibly better than zeitgeist but still not tier 1. also they make excellent breakfast items and a good chili.
author: christopher a.
